title: 111_hr2770
content: The Act titled "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" provides general authorities for the establishment of corporations. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" authorizes the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations to facilitate research and education at multiple medical centers. These corporations must have a board of directors that includes officials from each Department medical center involved. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" allows for the creation of multi-medical center research corporations to oversee research and education activities at multiple Department medical centers. These corporations can manage finances related to research and education conducted at the involved medical centers. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" allows for the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations under state nonprofit laws to facilitate research and education activities at Department medical centers. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" allows for the establishment of research and education corporations at Department medical centers under state nonprofit laws. The corporations and their personnel are required to comply with Federal laws and regulations. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" allows for the establishment of research and education corporations at Department medical centers under state nonprofit laws. These corporations must comply with applicable Federal laws, regulations, and executive orders. They are not owned or controlled by the United States or considered an agency of the United States. Additionally, the requirement for 501(c)(3) status of corporations is reinstated. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" clarifies the purposes of corporations established at Department medical centers under state nonprofit laws. These corporations must adhere to Federal laws and regulations, are not owned or controlled by the United States, and must have 501(c)(3) status reinstated. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" amends the purposes of corporations established at Department medical centers to provide funding for approved research and education, and to facilitate related functions. It also modifies the defined term 'education' to include education and training. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" amends the purposes of corporations at Department medical centers to fund research and education. It also expands the definition of 'education' to include training. Amendments include repealing the role of corporations with respect to fellowships and making education available for families of veteran patients. SEC. 4. Modification of requirements for boards of directors of corporations. Modification of requirements for Department Board Members in Department medical centers under title 38, United States Code, includes directors, chief of staff, associate chiefs of staff for research and education, or other responsible officials as needed. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to requirements for non-department board members, clarification that department employees may serve as executive directors, and conflicts of interest in section 7363 of title 38, United States Code. Amendment to conflicts of interest in section 7363 of title 38, United States Code by removing financial relationships. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF POWERS OF CORPORATIONS. Section 7364 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to give corporations the power to accept and administer funds, enter into contracts, set fees for education and training, and reimburse amounts to the Department's appropriation account. The Office of General Counsel can use funds for legal services related to research and education agreements, employ necessary staff, and set fees for education and training. Fees for training officers or employees of the Department cannot be paid with Department funds. Reimbursed amounts are for staff, training, and travel for legal services and have no fiscal year limitation. The Secretary can transfer funds for research or education at a Department medical center to a corporation for administration. The medical center can reimburse the corporation for employee expenses and retain funds provided by the corporation. The Department can transfer funds to a corporation for research and education projects, with funds credited to the appropriate account without fiscal year limitation. The corporation must follow approval procedures set by the Under Secretary for Health, including scientific review for research projects and approval for education activities. The Under Secretary for Health can prescribe policies and procedures for corporations established under this subchapter to guide fund spending in accordance with laws and regulations. Section 7362(a) of the title is amended by removing the last sentence. Section 7364A of title 38, United States Code, is redesignated as section 7365. The table of sections in chapter 73 is updated accordingly. Improved accountability and oversight of corporations is emphasized. Each corporation must submit an annual report detailing their operations and accomplishments. Corporations with revenues over $500,000 need an annual audit, while those with revenues between $100,000 and $500,000 require an audit every three years. The report to the Secretary must include the most recent audit and IRS Form 990. The IRS Form 990 and conflict of interest policies are required for corporations established under this subchapter. Each director, officer, and employee must adhere to the conflict of interest policy. The IRS Form 990 and conflict of interest policies are required for corporations under this subchapter. The provision is amended to increase the amount from $35,000 to $50,000.
